fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-5058].
  {panel}

A series of hyphens is not rendered into em-dash or en-dash if it is not surrounded by spaces.

I think that this is incorrect, because typographically, em-dashes should not be surrounded by spaces (see Wikipedia citation below).

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dash#En_dash

I am coming to Confluence from experience with Textile under drupal/PHP. In that environment, Textile does not require surrounding spaces.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-5031].
  {panel}

It would be very nice to be able to use the RSS Feed Builder to become more of a general Notification Feed Builder - which would define the content of the feed (abstracting it from the output mechanism). This would enable the addition of various outputs, the following 3 I think are most desirable:

1. RSS XML (already existing)
2. HTML - The above, when viewed in a browser, should look similar to search results (or possibly blog results showing multiple blogs)
3. Email Notification - Through "watching" the feed - linked from the feed main page, and from the html above.

This would allow the user to choose how s/he gets their notifications as everyone has their own preference, and far more people have an email reader than an rss reader.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-4867].
  {panel}

Hi,

I'm currently using Jetspeed and spring-portlet. I use a model layer which is handled by Spring and Hibernate : Services, DAOs and BOs. Services can open hibernate sessions to perform database requests. Portlet controllers call services to get the informations back. Everything works great except when I have to get a nested BO inside a BO in a controller.
For example :
IMyService myService = (IMyService) getService ("MyServiceName");
IMyBO myBO = myService.getMyBO(someParameters);
// At this point myBO is correctly instanciated and all fileds can be accessed.
IMyOtherBO myOtherBO = myBO.getMyOtherBO();
String info = myOtherBO.toString(); // Or .getAField()
//throws a LazyInitializationException : could not initialize proxy - the owning Session was closed;

So, I tried to configure my PortletModeParameterHandlerMapping with an OpenSessionInViewInterceptor to give myBO a session back.
In my xml conf file (like books.xml) :
<bean name="openSessionInViewInterceptor" class="org.springframework.web.portlet.support.hibernate3.OpenSessionInViewInterceptor">
<property name="sessionFactory"><ref bean="hibernateSessionFactory"/></property>
</bean>

<bean id="portletModeParameterHandlerMapping" class="org.springframework.web.portlet.handler.PortletModeParameterHandlerMapping">
<property name="interceptors">
<list>
<ref bean="parameterMappingInterceptor"/>
<ref bean="openSessionInViewInterceptor"/>
</list>
</property>
<property name="portletModeParameterMap">
<map>
<entry key="view">
<map> ... All my entries views ...
</map>
</entry>
</map>
</property>
</bean>

A session is correctly initialized before the render or action call and is correctly closed after.
The problem is that the CGLIBLazyInitializer proxy object of myBO doesn't use this session but still persists using the closed session.
How can I  force it to use the good session ?
Is there another solution to my problem ?

Thanks in advance,
Romain

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-4850].
  {panel}

When getting email notifications about comments being added, it is very easy to loose the context of the comment thread - especially when the comment is just "good idea! I'll get on it". I know there is a link which you can click to open up the web browser and go to page but there are situations where this is impractical (e.g. when reading through 100 notifications in your in-box in the morning and wanting to stay in your mail client) or impossible (e.g. when catching up with your mail notifications while on the train).

My suggestion is in the case of a comment being a reply-to that confluence appends the current comment thread (omitting the rest of the comments and page content). There are a few areas where this could be improved further:

1. If there are many comments in the thread (eg: 10 deep) it could be cut down to, say the latest 3.
2. If the past comments are very long and verbose (eg: stack traces) that it could be summarised with either the first 300 characters or somehow detecting and truncating large chunks (like stack traces).

Note that the newly added comment should be shown in its full entirety.

we would like to enable the trackback component between our Jira and Confluence installation. As I read in some discussions, we can´t finally use the trackback function because anonymous access is assumed on both sides. A solution was already described in the Jira issue JRA-5063 (http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-5063)

Best regards,
Heiko Burghardt

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Confluence allows the import/export of Microsoft Word document, but not the OpenDocument (.odt).
h3. Suggested Solution
Allow OpenDocument documents to be imported (converted to Wiki markup) and confluence pages to be exported as OpenDocument.

h3. Workaround 
There's no workaround at the moment.

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-4712].
  {panel}

The following comment was made by Björn Feustel on the Remote API Specification page:

"It would be great if the confluence xml-rpc service would support server introspection via system.listMethods so one could use tools like xml-rpc-api2txt to get the actual interface description."

We need to fix the problem of our remote api documentation getting out of sync with the source. Some form of automated querying of the remote interface that can generate some for of documentation would be ideal in supporting the accurate generation of the Remote API spec.

There may be come tool support to help in this.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-4572].
  {panel}

Currently, there is a single, globally-set thumbnail size that all thumbnails must adhere to. We should instead allow arbitrary thumbnail sizes.

/download/thumbnails/9999/image.jpg -- default thumbnail size (as before)
/download/thumbnails/9999/320x240/image.jpg -- 320x240 thumbnail size

And so on.

* Gallery macro and thumbnail properties for images will need to support the sizings
* We will need to periodically flush the thumbnail cache directory, though, since we could have an arbitrary number of thumbnail files per attachment.
* As it is now, the aspect ratio of the original image should be preserved - the 320x240 thumbnail should be the largest image that will fit into a 320x240 rectangle while preserving the original aspect ratio.
fields.summary: Allow arbitrary sized thumbnails

It would be nice if we had the following parameters (apologies if these have been added in a Confluence 2.x build):

* extensions = comma separated list of image extensions to include (default = all). Eg. I might just want to show .png's or .gif's
* size = override thumbnail size - I might want to show herds of images on a page so use a thumb size of 100px wheras another page might only have a small number of files so I might want them bigger, say 300px

(Yes, I know the thum size can be set in admin console, but it would be nice to be able to override it if necessary just for one page - or maybe even set a default on a space by space basis?)

Also, what image formats are supported?

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-4358].
  {panel}

At present, the {dynamictasklist} macro is only usable with a mouse. It would be nice to have some keyboard accessibility on there, specifically:

Add onkeypress attributes to the task status (complete/incomplete icon button) and delete link for each task. The onkeypress handler would do exactly the same as the onclick handler - a very quick way to add keyboard interactivity, at least for javascript enabled browsers.

In addition, the two links (task status and delete task) should also be given titles - not only will this allow for a more descriptive tooltip to be displayed, but it also aids people with screen readers, braillers, etc. Again, very simple to add.

In the "add task" box, it would be nice if the "Add Task" text was defined as a label with an attribute of for="newtask" and then give the input with name task an id="newTask" attrib. This is a very quick way to help people with screen readers, braillers, etc., know what the label relates to and also select the textbox.

The next bit isn't so simple (and as such is probably better farmed off to a sub-task of this issue) - compatibility with javascript-disabled browsers....

Your <a> tags for setting task status and deleting tasks currently have a href="#" which will obviously do nothing if there is no javascript support. For the task status, could you have the href set to a server side action that toggles the task status as part of a screen refresh? That way, if the user has JS enabled, they use the dynamic way of doing things, if they don't have JS they see the page refresh.

I'm guessing the delete task link would be slightly more complex - it will need a page displaying that asks if the user is sure they want to delete in the middle.

See also: CONF-4357
fields.summary: Improved accessibility for {dynamictasklist} macro
Make dynamictasklist's collapsable
